title: Managing water scarcity with better data | Hong Yang

tasks.task: Presenting and discussing ideas for managing water scarcity and enhancing food security in sub-Saharan Africa.
subtasks: Introduction to population growth and increasing food and water demands.
Explanation of irrigation's significant contribution to water withdrawal (70%).
Discussion of the challenges faced in producing more food with limited water resources.
Analysis of international trade's role in virtual water exchange.
Presentation of water scarcity maps and regions affected.
Discussion of low crop yields in sub-Saharan Africa (one-third global average).
Explanation of factors influencing yield growth through crop models and GIS simulation.
Interpretation of simulated results for maize yield in sub-Saharan Africa.
Examination of the impact of increased water supply versus fertilizer supply on yields.
Evaluation of the potential benefits of doubling or tripling maize yields in sub-Saharan Africa.
Addressing the challenge of sustainably tapping into Africa's food and virtual water potential.

tasks.task: Presenting ideas for managing water scarcity and enhancing food security in sub-Saharan Africa.
subtasks: Introduction to the increasing global population and its impact on food and water demands.
Explanation of irrigation's significant contribution to water usage, highlighting that 70% of withdrawn water resources are used for irrigation.
Discussion of the challenges in producing more food with limited water resources, noting that many rivers and lakes are drying up due to irrigation.
Presentation of the role of international trade in virtual water exchange, explaining that North America, South America, and Oceania are major food exporters.
Analysis of the water scarcity situation in sub-Saharan Africa, noting that while the region doesn't face physical water scarcity, crop yields are very low (one-third of global average).
Explanation of yield growth factors using crop models and GIS simulation, showing that increasing water supply has little impact on yields compared to fertilizer supply.
Examination of potential yield improvements: doubling yields could eliminate imports, while tripling could create surplus for export.
Addressing the challenge of sustainably unlocking Africa's potential to contribute to global food supply, emphasizing the need for sustainable, equitable, and economically viable solutions.
